ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Regarding field trips, we spent most of our time visiting museums and art galleries on the campus. And It has been one of the most enriching learning experiences of my life here in Yale.
Excellent course, wish more courses like this were available for Yale students.

A truly wonderful and unique class, one in which I absolutely count myself lucky to have taken it. There are few times in my life where I've been able to brag about how interesting the Professor and class is to friends, this was one of them.
This was a wonderful capstone to the human/environment interaction

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Explore Yale and nurture Yale identity
Going to the art galleries and the Beinecke to look at actual art and original documents related to the topics in the course.
Interdisciplinary nature and access to Yale collections at museums.
The Professor has an absolutely incredible base of knowledge, encourages open and honest discussion of the subject matter with no agenda or judgement.
Easily the best course I took at Yale. So sad Paul will no longer be teaching here.
Getting to know yale, and its resources through field trips
This is an amazing class. It connected history with environmental knowledge - while visiting YALE amazing galleries and museums. Even my wife used to joined me at every class!

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Discuss the full range of topics as outlined in the syllabus.
We need more student interaction, ability of students to think for themselves followed by what the instructor is thinking. A core 2 way conversation would have been good.
Nothing
Some of the museums we visited could use more sitting space.

We need a more precise syllabus that the professor sticks to. I feel like we just continued to talk about Tibetan Buddhism for each course. While very interesting, I feel like we only touched on archetypes every other class.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: There should be an option for students to dissect art work first followed by the instructor's narration on the subject matter.
The course lectures were centered around the subjects we were studying, whether it be in a museum, the city, or the campus itself.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: I am exploring the longstanding connections between creativity, spirituality and nature. This course covered those areas quite well.

It did not fit into my learning strategy at all, which is what made it so magical. This course is the kind of thing people who don't attend Yale imagine Yale students take all the time, but it's actually quite rare. Big loss for FES.
Provides context to all environmentalists

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I wanted to know more about Yale. I also want to expolre the annex of ancient cultures and modern science regarding nature.
I am very interested in the study of archetypes, particularly how they show up in society.

There is more to nature than just finance, GIS and what not. There is another aspect to our world and its important that we have courses like this. Albeit it would have been nice if we had a structure involving more student interaction.
It sounded like a unique class, and indeed it was.
Came with very good recommendations from previous students.
Interest, heard good things about the Professor.
It seemed relevant to my interests: as students at FES we are all in some way mediators between humankind and the natural environment. I only wish we had studied it more in depth!
I was curious and wanted to take a risk on a course with a syllabus that sounded fascinating but completely incomprehensible. So glad I did, the risk paid off.
It was highly recommended by past students
I heard that Paul would explain what's YALE. He did.
To shake up my quant heavy schedule

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes.
Yes, however, I would have liked to have learned more about the Celtic traditions as described on the syllabus.
Yes.
Yes.
Yes, truly a wonderful and enlightening class.
Exceeded my expectations.
Exceeded my expectations

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: We were in a affinity group, which encouraged discussions among people with like minded in the class. This helped the students to delve deeper into the topics that are most interesting to us.
Learning how others interepret the ideas of nature through religious belief and art. I had the opportunity to be in a group with international students which added new insights.

Navigating disparate interests is always a fascinating endeavor, however it's encouraged and facilitated by the Professor in an easygoing and beneficial fashion. Aside from the focus on creating and attempting whatever project(s) decided upon, leads to increased cohesion between the team members and an enlightening sharing of ideas and perspectives.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Do it!
That they should demand to take the course.
Do it! Hopefully it'll be online soon!
Take it
YALE has many wonderful stuff to show. An historical perspective on the environment is one of them.
This class is amazing. You learn so much about the history of Yale, environmentalism, the world. It's a shame that students will no longer have the opportunity to take this course.
